info.name: Lab 03 - Challenge
info.description: ## Collection Notes: CONGRATS! You've made it to the challenge section. This area is intended for attendees to solve and build solo/alone within Postman. Please try to remember to create the calls in a manner in which you piggyback IDs/data from prior calls. This will help you to achieve automation and run the collection (or subfolder) with Postman Runner ## Your Challenge: You need to bring in some new Surveys (or CSAT) data within Platform in order to enrich customer details. The data has been placed into an s3 bucket (details forthcoming) and will land on a daily basis. ## Survey Data: Here is a sample JSON record to serve as an example of what data will be brought into Platform ``` json { "_id": "f60ac4af-61f3-4a5a-b3a8-e9d243d283cd", "_devbc": { "csatData": { "surveyDate": "2022-03-03T19:40:33Z", "surveyId": "b5087729-a4a9-47e5-a34a-b1838e9b7e62", "surveyType": "in-store", "ratePlan": 3, "rateCustomerService": 9, "rateProducts": 6, "rateSpeed": 3 }, "idDetails": { "email": "jethington0@etsy.com", "crmId": "8497125872" } } } ``` ## Survey Data Columns/Fields: | **JSON Field** | **Notes** | **Data Type** | | --- | --- | --- | | `csatData` | object containing values/attributes collected in the survey | Object | | `surveyDate` | when the survey was conducted (DATE) | DATE | | `surveyId` | unique ID of the survey -- could be used in future lookups (another lab in another day) (STRING | STRING | | `surveyType` | where the | STRING | | `ratePlan` | rating (1-10) on Plan Satisfaction | INTEGER | | `rateCustomerService` | rating (1-10) on Customer Service | INTEGER | | `rateProducts` | rating (1-10) on Product Offering | INTEGER | | `rateSpeed` | rating (1-10) on Service Speed | INTEGER | | `idDetails.email` | customer email address (NOTE: this field is sometimes not always populated) | STRING | | `idDetails.crmId` | unique customer ID (always populated) | STRING | ## Other Data Specifics: | **Aspect** | **Value** | | --- | --- | | s3 Location | `summit2023lab/csat_data/xdm/` | | File format name | `2023_03_01_csat_data.json` | | Mockaroo Location (Public URL) | [https://mockaroo.com/813545e0](https://mockaroo.com/813545e0) | ## Some Help: - Please consider copying prior calls (in Lab 01 and 02) as you may need to re-use those components - Please read the notes about the certain fields - Consider copying some code from Lab 2 - 2.1 - Step 1 (it's got some good stuff there) - If you need to restart creating objects/items (while in the middle of the challenge), please consider to reset/delete items with the -- Reset Challenge -- scripts - The areas with ???? = need to be fixed/changed in the lab - Please consider to NOT change the call names within Postman -- there's some conditional logic that's used to control whether or not schema/dataset gets promoted to Profile - Preflight Step - set this to "yes" if you wish to promote items to Profile. By default, the "no" setting will allow for Postman Runner to "skip" promotion to Profile - Note: schema based items (custom data types, field groups, schemas) cannot be deleted once promoted to Profile (see above comment). ## Labeling: | Assumed Naming Conventions | Value | | --- | --- | | Field Group - CSAT Responses | `{{lab_number}}: CSAT Responses` | | Field Group - Customer IDs | `{{lab_number}}: Customer Identities` | | Schema (CSAT) | `{{lab_number}}: CSAT Data` | | Dataset (CSAT) | `{{lab_number}}: CSAT Data` | | Flow (CSAT) | `{{lab_number}}: Dataflow for CSAT Data via AWS S3 - {{AWS_YEAR}}` | | Account (CSAT) | `{{lab_number}}: AWS S3 Storage Account - Summit (CSAT)` | ## Extra Credit: Already done? Please take a look at some common advanced example of operations within Platform ## Collection Calls:

request.description: ## Call Objective: - The BODY is the design of a new namespace - POST [https://platform.adobe.io/data/core/idnamespace/identities](https://platform.adobe.io/data/core/idnamespace/identities) ## Lab Task: - Make sure 201 response occurs - Make note of the `code` used, this is needed for delcaring identitiy descriptors in the schema - Notice that `idType` is critical for backend stitching (UIS graph) ## Response Example: ## Body Analysis: | **idType** | **comments** | **Unified Identity Service (UIS) Stitching** | | --- | --- | --- | | `CROSS_DEVICE` | Cross-device IDs identify an individual and usually tie other IDs together | YES | | `Email` | Email addresses are often associated with a single person and therefore can be used to identify that person across different channels | YES | | `Phone` | Phone numbers are often associated with a single person and therefore can be used to identify that person across different channels | YES | | `COOKIE` | Cookie IDs identify web browsers | YES | | `Device` | Device IDs identify hardware devices | YES | | `Non-people` | Non-people IDs are used for storing identifiers that require namespaces _**but are not connected to a person cluster**_. For example, a product SKU, data related to products, organizations, or stores. | NO -- but it does match/connect keys together (very much like SAINT or matchtables) | ## Key Takeaways: - This creates a new field group (mixin) that can be used in a schema ## Notice: - Custom namespaces created in `prod` are _**NOT allowed to be deleted/reset**_ - Custom namespaces created in `sandboxes` (not `prod`) can be deleted only upon sandbox reset - Attempt to re-create an already submitted namespace will result in a 409 response (nothing changes/breaks in the backend) ## API Library Location: - Identity Service - Identity Namespaces - Create new identity namespace ## Documentation Links: - [https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/identity/namespaces.html](https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/identity/namespaces.html) - [https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/identity/api/create-custom-namespace.html?lang=en](https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/identity/api/create-custom-namespace.html?lang=en) - [https://developer.adobe.com/experience-platform-apis/references/identity-service/#tag/Identity-Namespace/operation/retrieveIdentityNamespace](https://developer.adobe.com/experience-platform-apis/references/identity-service/#tag/Identity-Namespace/operation/retrieveIdentityNamespace)

request.description: ## Call Objective: - Creates a custom field group with the schema registry - Utilize the POST method [https://platform.adobe.io/data/foundation/schemaregistry/tenant/mixins/](https://platform.adobe.io/data/foundation/schemaregistry/tenant/mixins/Body) StartFragment ## Lab Task: - Goto the "Tests" tab - Capture the `$id` and `meta:altId` values of this Field Group (FG) ## Body Analysis | **Required Values** | **Comments** | | --- | --- | | `title` | The name of the field group you wish to create within the schema registry. Note the name MUST BE UNIQUE. | | `description` | A short description about the purpose of the field group | | `type` | Always an object | | `meta:intendedToExtend` | Defines what classes the field group can be used with. Classes are always referenced by their `$id` value | | `allOf` | A list of resources whose properties are to be inheritied by the new class | | `definitions...` | This contains the fields that make up the field group. Note the use of the `$ref` lists the path to the data type we created | | `{{TENANT_ID}}` | This is your tenant name (i.e. unique name) that is created during the provisioning process. This ensures that any customizations made are unique to only your IMS Org | ## Response Example: ## Response Analysis: | **variables** | **comments** | | --- | --- | | `$id` | JSON Schema standard identifier in the form of a URI used for all XDM resources | | `meta:altId` | REST friendly version of the $id expressed in dot notation | | `definitions...` | This contains the fields that make up the field group. Note the use of the `$ref` lists the path to the data type we created | | `meta:intendedToExtend` | Defines where this field group is allowed | | `allOf` | A list of resources whose properties are to be inherited by the new class. | ## Key Takeaways: - This creates a new field group (mixin) that can be used in a schema

request.description: ## Call Objective: - The BODY is the design of the schema - POST [https://platform.adobe.io/data/foundation/schemaregistry/tenant/mixins/](https://platform.adobe.io/data/foundation/schemaregistry/tenant/mixins/) ## Lab Task: - Please insert/paste the correct `$ref` values within the BODY payload ## Body Example: ## Body Analysis | **variables** | **comments** | | --- | --- | | `title` | friendly name that shows in the UI (REQUIRED) | | `description` | gives more context to the schema (OPTIONAL) | | `allOf` | this is an array with all the components (each `$ref` value) that build out the schema | | `$ref` | there's eseentially 3 different types of values that are used here: (1) declaring the class (2) OOTB field groups and (3) Custom field groups | ## Schema Components: ## Response Example: ## Response Analysis: | **variables** | **comments** | | --- | --- | | `$id` | primary ID needed in schema creation | | `meta:altId` | sometimes used in other places (_usually_ not as useful as `$id` ) | ## Key Takeaways: - This creates a new field group (mixin) that can be used in a schema ## API Library Location: - Schema Registry API - Schemas - Create a custom schema

request.description: ## Call Objective: - The BODY is the details of the credentials/account - POST [https://platform.adobe.io/data/foundation/flowservice/connections](https://platform.adobe.io/data/foundation/flowservice/connections) ## Lab Task: - Within your Collection variables, please add + save these IDs so Postman Runner uses them ## Response Example: ## Body Analysis: | **key vars** | **comments** | | --- | --- | | `s3AccessKey` | s3 bucket Access Key | | `s3SecretKey` | s3 bucket Secret Key | | `connectionSpec.id` | This specifies which connection is being used (obtained from last step) | ## Key Takeaways: - This creates a new connection - A single connection can control multiple dataflows (albeit from the same source) ## API Library Location: - Flow Service API - Connections - Create a new connection ## Documentation Links: - [https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/sources/api-tutorials/create/cloud-storage/s3.html?lang=en](https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/sources/api-tutorials/create/cloud-storage/s3.html?lang=en)

request.description: ## Call Objective: - The BODY is the details of the source location (and data aspects) - POST [https://platform.adobe.io/data/foundation/flowservice/sourceConnections](https://platform.adobe.io/data/foundation/flowservice/sourceConnections) ## Lab Task: - Within your Collection variables, please add + save these IDs so Postman Runner uses them ## Response Example: ## Body Analysis: | **key vars** | **comments** | | --- | --- | | `baseConnectionId` | previous id from the source/account connection | | `data.format` | sepcifies the data formatting | | `params.path` | location of the data -- please note that in the API call you can use limited regex "\*" pattern matching to collect more than a single file (UI does not support this) | | `params.recursive` | recursive look into the location | | `connectionSpec.id` | um,,, | ## Key Takeaways: - This creates a new source information (for a dataflow) ## API Library Location: - Flow Service API - Source connections - Create a new source connection ## Documentation Links: - [https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/sources/api-tutorials/create/cloud-storage/s3.html?lang=en](https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/sources/api-tutorials/create/cloud-storage/s3.html?lang=en)

request.description: ## Call Objective: - The BODY is the details of the target location (schema + dataset) - POST [https://platform.adobe.io/data/foundation/flowservice/targetConnections](https://platform.adobe.io/data/foundation/flowservice/targetConnections) ## Lab Task: - Within your Collection variables, please add + save these IDs so Postman Runner uses them ## Response Example: ## Body Analysis: | **key vars** | **comments** | | --- | --- | | `data.format` | specifies the data formatting expected to land | | `data.schema.id` | schema ID (created prior) | | `params.dataSetId` | dataset ID (created prior) | | `connectionSpec.id` | datalake connector ID (from catalogue) -- ask Nipun about this (why it's this way???) | ## Key Takeaways: - This creates a new source information (for a dataflow) ## API Library Location: - Flow Service API - Target connections - Create a new target connection ## Documentation Links: - [https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/sources/api-tutorials/create/cloud-storage/s3.html?lang=en](https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/sources/api-tutorials/create/cloud-storage/s3.html?lang=en)

request.description: ## Call Objective: - The BODY is the details of the dataflow (source + target combination -- the executiion of the feed) - POST [https://platform.adobe.io/data/foundation/flowservice/flows](https://platform.adobe.io/data/foundation/flowservice/flows) ## Lab Task: - Within your Collection variables, please add + save these IDs so Postman Runner uses them ## Response Example: ## Body Analysis: | **key vars** | **comments** | | --- | --- | | `flowSpec.id` | forgot where this thing lives | | `sourceConnectionIds` | source connection ID (created prior) | | `targetConnectionIds` | target connection ID (created prior) | | `transformations` | in this example, nothing is used since data is already in XDM-compliant JSON format. Within the extra credit section, we'll use Mapper (data prep) to transform data into the schema/dataset format | | `scheduleParams` | settings for how often data will be pulled (on poll). Please note that typically the "smallest" interval of time is 15 mins. `{{ts}}` is current UNIX TIME calculated. Ask Nipun (docs?) backfill also ad hoc as a value | ## Key Takeaways: - This creates a new a new dataflow -- tying together all the prior steps ## API Library Location: - Flow Service API - Flows - Create a flow ## Documentation Links: - [https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/sources/api-tutorials/create/cloud-storage/s3.html?lang=en](https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/sources/api-tutorials/create/cloud-storage/s3.html?lang=en)

request.description: ## Call Objective: - Get a list of all the different "amazon-s3" connector spec IDs for later operations ## Lab Task: - Same call seen in (2.1 - Step 2) - This JS code, within Tests, is similar to the previous example - Instead of hard coding the spec IDs (which is an option), this will loop through and find the correct/matching spec ID as it relates to the s3 bucket being a (1) Source into AEP or (2) Destination. ## Tests Analysis: | **code blocks** | **comments** | | --- | --- | | `var data = JSON.parse(responseBody);` | takes the response Body and casts it into a JSON object which can be used to extract/loop through data | | `var elementCount = data.items.length;` | Getting the count of elements within "items" array in response (in other API calls, it could be "results" instead of items) | | `for (var counter = 0; counter < elementCount; counter++)` | This will loop through all items (individually) until it reaches the end of the count | | `if (data.items[counter]["attributes"]["isSource"] == true )` | This looks for a particular value in the item. In this case it's {"attributes":{"isSource": true}} | | `postman.setEnvironmentVariable("AWS_S3_SPEC_ID", data.items[counter]["id"]);` | Like what was seen earlier, this sets the variable | | `console.log(pm.environment.get("AWS_S3_SPEC_ID"));` | This prints the extracted value into the Postman console | ## Scripting Notes: - Everything is in JS - Certain code/commands tie into Postman Runner (which we'll see very soon) ## Response Example: ## Response Analysis: | **variables** | **comments** | | --- | --- | | `id` | spec ID (needed for source + target connections) | | `name` | friendly name of the connection spec | | `authSpec` | specific settings on the connection | | `attributes` | attributes/metadata about the connection | ## Key Takeaways: - This API shows the spec IDs along with the other parameters/settings needed for deploying connections (for both source and destination) ## API Library Location: - Flow Service API - Connection specs - List connection specifications

request.description: ## Call Objective: - The BODY is the details of the credentials/account ## Lab Task: - This POST creates the initial account connection in Amazon s3 bucket - Notice that no storage locations/pathways are specified here, that happens later ## Body Example: ## Body Analysis: | **key vars** | **comments** | | --- | --- | | `s3AccessKey` | s3 bucket Access Key | | `s3SecretKey` | s3 bucket Secret Key | | `connectionSpec.id` | This specifies which connection is being used (obtained from last step) | | `name` | Name of the account connection (should be unique) | ## Response Example: ## Coding Loops: - Please notice the extra code happening within `Pre-request Script` and `Tests` - This is necessary in the event of Amazon (or whichever service for that matter) doesn't respond in time after a connection attempt occurs - Typically, loop coding is only needed in scenarios where other 3rd party services are called and might not respond in a timely manner ## Key Takeaways: - This creates a new connection - A single connection can control multiple dataflows (albeit from the same source) ## API Library Location: - Flow Service API - Connections - Create a new connection ## Documentation Links: - [https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/sources/api-tutorials/create/cloud-storage/s3.html?lang=en](https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/sources/api-tutorials/create/cloud-storage/s3.html?lang=en)

request.description: ## Call Objective: - The BODY is the details of the dataflow (source + target combination -- the execution of the feed) - This is the final step that completes the feed ## Lab Task: - No action is needed ## Body Example: ## Body Analysis: | **key vars** | **comments** | | --- | --- | | `flowSpec.id` | forgot where this thing lives | | `sourceConnectionIds` | source connection ID (created prior) | | `targetConnectionIds` | target connection ID (created prior) | | `transformations` | in this example, nothing is used since data is already in XDM-compliant JSON format. Within the extra credit section, we'll use Mapper (data prep) to transform data into the schema/dataset format | | `scheduleParams` | settings for how often data will be pulled (on poll). Please note that typically the "smallest" interval of time is 15 mins. `{{ts}}` is current UNIX TIME calculated. | ## Response Analysis: ## Key Takeaways: - This creates a new a new dataflow -- tying together all the prior steps ## API Library Location: - Flow Service API - Flows - Create a flow ## Documentation Links: - [https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/sources/api-tutorials/create/cloud-storage/s3.html?lang=en](https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/sources/api-tutorials/create/cloud-storage/s3.html?lang=en)
